reviewText: This is a great movie that dates back to my childhood. I remember seeing this movie on television one night with my mother. Cougars are one of my favorite wild animals because of my association with hiking the Grand Canyon where cougars live. Anyway, this movie brought back so many wonderful memories that I shared with my best friend, my Mother!!!!!  Thank You Amazon for bringing my childhood back with this great movie. I can't remember what I paid for this movie but I know it was well worth it!

reviewText: This movie is a great family movie for those who like animals. My family and I enjoyed it. The cougar/mountain lion is great fun to see...he's a beautiful big cat and very smart. The story line is cute and doesn't get too intense...all the problems work out without too much crises. Classic Disney. :)

Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a cute inconsequential movie that used to serve as part of a Disney double feature back in the 60s.  These types of movies were never long or challenging in plot.  In this particular case, you have minimal acting with Rex Allen narrating the story of a cougar and his mini-adventures/escapades.  This movie was filmed in the Columbia River Gorge in Washington.  It takes great advantage of the landscape.  It's a fun piece, nothing substantial, lots of slapstick humor.  (Amusingly enough, I recall seeing this movie in a theater, paired with a main feature.  This movie I fondly remember, and just had to have for my collection, what the main feature was I can't recollect.)

reviewText: THIS is the Disney I remember and adored!  THIS is the kind of programming I would like my grandkids watching.  Disney has forgotten what is not only entertaining, but educational, too.  I love these as much now as I did then.  As much as my children loved them, and as much as THEIR children do.  Hannah Montana???  What were they thinking?
summary: Walt, where are you when we need you?

reviewText: The VHS I have of this is longer and has better color. I'm not sure what is missing but a few minutes are definitely gone. The print has faded to a blue or grey overcast which is a shame because much of the movie is shot outdoors in the Pacific Northwest amid some really beautiful scenery.This print really needs to be cleaned up and the missing footage restored.But it's still a great movie for kids.

reviewText: The most beautiful movie of all time. This movie will stay in my heart forever. If you are an animal lover like me then I don't have to tell you how much I enjoy looking at animal shows. I am an animal activist and believe in letting animals be themselves. Charlie had a personality all his own. He was very young and lonely. His owner realized that charlie needed companionship and that working and raising a wild animal was not going to work. The part that I loved was when the owner took charlie to a part of the woods where he wouldn't get hurt and charlie found the female he played with when he was young. Both of them parted on good terms.Beautiful!

reviewText: Charlie the Lonesome Cougar is a story about a man named Jess Bradley who adopts an orphaned cougar cub and names him Good Time Charlie or Charlie for short.Charlie soon becomes the star of the lumber mill where Jess works.  Everyone loves him except for the local dog Chainsaw.  He gives Charlie fits that'll leave you laughing for a long time.  The very idea of a little fox terrier being able to scare a cougar is ridiculous, but Charlie didn't know he was a cougar.When Charlie gets bigger he starts causing a lot of problems at the lumber mill which leads to his banishment.  After that he escapes into the wild and actually lives as a wild cougar for a time.  He eventually makes his way back to the lumber mill, but by this time he is more wild than tame.I give the DVD 4 instead of 5 stars because in the Wonderful World of Disney version there's a scene not in the DVD that explains how Charlie gets his name.  He is pestering Jess and knocking papers off his table onto the floor, and Jess says, "I guess I can't keep saying Hey You all the time, so I'll call you Good Time Charlie."  For some reason, this scene is omitted from the VHS and DVD releases of the movie.  Also the mono instead of stereo or 5.1 soundtrack, but it's still great.

reviewText: Charlie The Lonesome Cougar (1967) is an adventure tale that features a real cougar as its star.  Using real animals, it's the kind of movie that was a Disney specialty, and along with TV programs like Lassie, Gentle Ben, Flipper, and Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom, was the kind of entertainment that a generation of kids in the 60's grew up with.The story is very simple, as a forester named Jess Bradley (Ron Brown), discovers a young cougar cub in the woods in Montana, and takes him home.  The male cub is named Charlie, and grows up becoming used to being around people, and other animals like dogs.  Jess works for the Carbon County Lumber Company, and Charlie routinely accompanies him to work.  The young cougar has some exciting adventures at a logging camp, taking a wild ride down a river, and later gets into mischief at a lumber mill.  Charlie eventually gets loose, and learns how to survive in the wild, having further adventures with other animals, and one startled farmer.  Eventually Charlie makes his way back to the lumber mill, panicking the workers.  The cougar is on the verge of being shot, when he recognizes his old friend Jess, and is briefly taken back into captivity, before being released in a protected wildlife refuge, to happily live the rest of his days in the Big Sky country.The kind of warm feel-good adventure that Disney was known for, Charlie the Lonesome Cougar features a truly remarkable performance by the cougars playing Charlie.  The animals are obviously very well trained, as the cougars perform a myriad of tasks and actions, and also some astounding tricks and stunts.  The cougar's interaction with both his human and animal co-stars is at times astonishing.  There are so many shots where it is obvious that there are no animal handlers anywhere nearby.  The cougar does all kinds of things involving logs, walking on moving logs in a river, riding on them in a sluice, pushing them in a log jam, and even jumping on one to challenge a man in a log rolling contest!  Much of this footage appears to feature a real animal, and if so, is quite impressive.  Charlie also has some terrific interactive scenes with other animals, including `Chainsaw' a fox terrier, other dogs, a bear cub, some cats, a cow, a hog, some sheep, deer, and another cougar, as well as a confrontation with a very feisty raccoon.In modern times, when animated animal characters can do such amazing things, it might be easy to take for granted Charlie's real life exploits.  If you keep in mind that this is a live animal, and one that is by its nature a hunter and killer, you might appreciate what a really remarkable achievement this performance is.  Check out those teeth when Charlie snarls!  Watching the cougar in the wild, running and leaping, and you get a real appreciation for the grace, balance, and immense power the animal possesses.The film does take a dated and traditionally folksy Disney approach to storytelling, using the iconic Rex Allen to narrate the tale.  It's pretty corny, but this was a popular style back then, and the narration along with the lively musical score, really does help to make the story flow along.  The acting by the humans is often stiff and pretty goofy, but the people are mostly used as setups for the Cougar and other critters.  Give Ron Brown and the rest cast credit for bravery, as many work side by side with the big cat.  This is a classic example of Disney's work in this genre, and a particularly impressive one, as featuring a performing cougar was probably a bit more challenging than working with an animal like a dog.  With a pretty good story, and lots of great action scenes with animals, Charlie the Lonesome Cougar is highly recommended family entertainment.
summary: Charlie the Lonesome Cougar, a classic Disney live animal adventure...
